head.title: It's Great New, But in 5 Years?

identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Sales and Business Development
identified-content.org: Acura Division of Honda Motor Co

hedline.hl1: It's Great New, But in 5 Years?
hedline.hl2: Itâ€™s Great New, but in 5 Years?

block.p: WHEN buying a vehicle, consumers may need to think about more than price. Depreciation can be just as important.

Checking depreciation before you get to the showroom does not carry the same hint of mistrust as handing your spouse a prenuptial agreement on your wedding day. After all, you will part with your car someday.
When buying a vehicle, consumers may need to think about more than price. Depreciation can be just as important.
WHEN buying a vehicle, consumers may need to think about more than price. Depreciation can be just as important.

Checking depreciation before you get to the showroom does not carry the same hint of mistrust as handing your spouse a prenuptial agreement on your wedding day. After all, you will part with your car someday.
The average vehicle loses about 65 percent of its original value after five years, according to Kelley Blue Book. So a new car costing $20,000 will be worth about $7,000 after five years.
But some brands and models retain their value better than others. Every year Kelley Blue Book guides consumers through depreciation with its Best Resale Value Awards.
The awards are based on the company's Residual Value Guide, which projects the value of vehicles at the end of five years.
More information is available at www.kbb.com/resaleaward.
2007 BEST RESALE VALUE BY BRAND Honda and Acura (tie)

2007 BEST RESALE BY CATEGORY Sedan: Acura TSX Coupe: Honda Civic Convertible: Mini Cooper Wagon: Volkswagen Passat Hatchback: Mini Cooper Luxury: BMW 5 Series Pickup: Toyota Tacoma Sport Utility: Acura MDX Van/Minivan: Honda Odyssey Hybrid: Toyota Prius
